awd_titl_txt: Dehn Surgery, Four-Manifolds, and Symplectic Topology
awd_abstract_narration:
Topology is an area of mathematics that studies the intrinsic shapes of objects, such as a hula hoop, a massive data set, our universe, or a strand of DNA.  For example, topology can be used to measure how biological processes change the shape of our DNA.   Surprisingly, these shape changes can be analyzed through three- and four-dimensional manifolds, fundamental shapes in topology that appear throughout mathematics and physics.  This leads to the fundamental problem of trying to completely understand and classify these three- and four-dimensional manifolds.  While we understand many aspects of three-dimensional objects, in dimension four we are still mostly in the dark.  One effective tool for studying these objects is called Floer homology, which comes from solving powerful equations from physics.  In this project, the PI will use Floer homology to study the complexity of these shapes by analyzing the configurations of knotted loops and surfaces inside of them.  The potential outcome of this project will be to strengthen connections between knots and three-/four-dimensional manifolds while discovering new structure in the topology of four-dimensional manifolds.  This project will then be disseminated to the public through a collaboration with Black Box Dance Theater, a North Carolina non-profit dance company.  By way of dance performances and public workshops, this will present to the public the fundamental notions of topology used in the proposed project.  This joint project will also work to improve public perception of mathematics and enhance connections between STEM and the arts.

Knots can be used to produce new three- and four-manifolds by an operation called Dehn surgery, where one removes a tubular neighborhood and reglues via a homeomorphism.  Many invariants and tools in low-dimensional topology, especially Floer homology, are particularly well-behaved under Dehn surgery, and the PI will use these tools to improve our understanding of three- and four-manifolds and further their connections with knot theory.  Three major goals of this project are to: 1) construct homology three-spheres which cannot be obtained by Dehn surgery on a two-component link, 2) find new constraints on the algebraic topology of four-manifolds admitting symplectic structures, and 3) further explore the algebraic structure of the concordance group of knots in homology spheres modulo concordance in homology cobordisms.  Two potential outcomes would be a better understanding of the complexity of four-manifolds with boundary measured in terms of their handlebody structures and a stronger connection between properties of a knot and the topology of its Dehn surgeries.

por.por_cntn:
The intellectual merit of this grant was focused on exploring topology, which is the mathematics of shape.  One special case of this is studying knots, which are theoretical models for closed loops of string.  These shapes arise, for instance, when studying the properties and structures of DNA .  Mathematical knot theory can be used to analyze and predict how these objects change under certain biological processes.  One outcome of this grant was understanding how a particular process, recombination, acts on a simple knot, called the trefoil.  The project also produced several other theoretic tools for studying knots as well as a new computational technique, including means of measuring how a collection of several knots can be linked together.  Another important method for studying problems in knot theory, including recombination problems, involves studying three- and four-dimensional objects called manifolds, and the PI produced several new theoretical results in the theory of manifolds which are likely to have further applications to knot theory.  This included solving a major 40 year old open problem about spheres in four-dimensional manifolds.  Overall, the PI produced over 15 new publications under the support of this grant.  The PI also trained a postdoc and three graduate students in knot theory as well as three- and four-dimensional manifolds under this grant, and they produced several new publications under this support.     

Another major focus of the grant was to broaden mathematics education.  In particular, the PI taught topology to non-mathematicians through the lens of dance.  This was done through collaboration with a local dance company, Black Box Dance Theatre, where the PI put on a large-scale performance "Applied Dance + Inspired Mathematics", educational workshops, public lectures, and a podcast where we taught the main ideas of topology through dance.  These activities involved many people from groups traditionally underrepresented in mathematics and aimed to dispel stigma around mathematics, involve community members with mathematics, and build excitement towards its importance through an innovative delivery.  The program particularly engaged K-12, college students, and community members who were not primarily interested in mathematics.  Black Box Dance Theatre also used this material in their educational program with K-12 schools to teach mathematics throughout the state of North Carolina.  

The PI also co-organized several conferences, both for researchers and for undergraduates.  The PI also helped to create the Virtual Low-Dimensional Topology community, which hosted regular seminars and meetings with senior mathematicians in the area of topology.  This provided important exposure for junior mathematicians to new research and connect them to the mathematical community in general during a time when in-person activities were suspended.  Both the undergraduate conferences and virtual community included important programming for professional development.
